newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai rice mart lull, '97 sales seen below target.
newsitem.headline: Thai rice mart lull, '97 sales seen below target.

text.p: The Thai rice market was quiet with no fresh buying heard over the week and prices remained steady, traders said.
Activity was focused mostly on covering. However, most exporters slowed down buying in an attempt to pressure prices and most of them were well-covered, they added.
Thai benchmark 100 percent grade B was quoted at $335-370 per tonne and 100 percent fragrant at $690-700, unchanged from last week.
Exporters projected rice exports for 1997 below the government target of 5.0-5.5 million tonnes as the sale of lower grade rice was not competitive.
Somboon Pathaichat, the manager of Thai Rice Exporters Association, said total exports this year might be only 4.8 million tonnes.

He said exports in the first quarter of this year amounted to 1.04 million tonnes, below 1.40 million in the same period last year. January-March rice exports fetched 10.81 billion baht against 13.62 billion baht last year.
"High quality rice is still competitive. But the performance of lower grade rice was not very good," he said.
"Our prices are quite high now compared to that of our competitors such as Vietnam, India or Pakistan. Thai fragrant rice, for example, is more expensive than Basmati now," he said.

Somboon blamed hoarding by merchants for high prices but expected Thailand to ship at least an average of 400,000 tonnes of rice a month for the remaining nine months. Currently, 14 vessels are loading 76,100 tonnes of rice, mostly for Asian destinations.
